awd_titl_txt: Garden State LSAMP Bridges to the Doctorate at Rutgers University, Newark
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on PhD matriculation and completion.  BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2018-2022 Strategic Plan, namely to "foster the growth of a more capable and diverse research workforce and advance the scientific and innovation skills of the Nation."  The vision of this grant is to provide a national model to produce underrepresented scientists and engineers with doctoral degrees in STEM.

The performance site for this LSAMP BD Activity is Rutgers University, Newark, one of the eight college and universities included in the Garden State Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (GSLSAMP).  The project will recruit a cohort of 12 qualified LSAMP fellows and support them financially, academically and socially through their graduate program using an innovative flexible structure that is individualized to the desires and needs of the fellow.  In addition to providing substantial financial support to enable students to focus full time on graduate-level course work and research, the project provides an integrated set of best practices designed to advance BD students toward completion of doctoral level studies.  The best practices include tracking/monitoring, critical point interventions, Graduate Research Fellowship Program and other support workshops, bridge-to-the-bridge orientation, post-doctoral application workshops and others.  The optional activities include opportunities with the Minority Biomedical Research Support program, GSLSAMP, the Newark STEAM coalition ecosystem and the wealth of professional, educational, outreach and research STEM opportunities in the New York metropolitan area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Garden State LSAMP 2020 Bridges to the Doctorate (BD) project at Rutgers University in Newark, NJ recruited 12 LSAMP graduates as a cohort of graduate fellows in non-medical STEM. They are in the departments of biology, chemistry, earth & environmental sciences and physics. The BD Fellows received stipends and academic, career and personal support for two years. As a result of the Covid-19 lockdown, programming in the 2020-2021 academic year was all virtual and it was virtual or restricted in much of the 2021-2022 academic year. In 2020-2021, the project was offered collaboratively with a NIH-funded G-RISE project at Rutgers University, Newark with graduate students of similar background thus expanding the learning community. BD programming delivered professional development workshops on STEM research ethics, STEM research careers, reading and writing professional journal articles, research collaborations, writing grant proposals, conference abstract preparation, professional presentations, applying for post-doctoral fellowships and preparing NSF Graduate Research Fellowship (GRFP) and Ford Foundation Fellowship proposals. These topics were chosen both by the directors and by popular vote of the BD Fellows. In addition, taking advantage of the new acceptability of virtual meetings, the cohort had presentations by underrepresented minority professionals from industry, federal labs, a major museum, the National Science Foundation, the US Geological Survey and research, 4-year and community college faculty on their career preparation and the pros and cons of their positions. These professionals then served as career mentors to the BD Fellows, as needed, for one year following their presentation and even served on their dissertation committees when asked.

Faculty research mentors of the BD Fellows attended workshops on best practices to advise and mentor underrepresented minority graduate students. These workshops were offered by the BD administrators using the latest methods as well as social psychologists who presented on such additional issues as implicit bias. These faculty mentors also participated in discussions to air difficulties and develop creative group solutions to overcome them. BD Fellows were also trained on mentoring undergraduate LSAMP assistants. They were each offered an LSAMP research assistant to participate in their dissertation research and most BD Fellows accepted the assistance. Unfortunately, the Covid-19 lockdown severely limited the outreach portion of the project. BD Fellows participated in panel discussions at the Garden State LSAMP annual research conferences to assist LSAMP undergraduates in pursuing graduate education. However, the proposed required community outreach had to be made optional because so many of the planned opportunities were suspended during the pandemic. At least half of the BD Fellows participated in some form of outreach on a voluntary basis to date.

Eleven of the 12 recruited BD Fellows completed the Rutgers University LSAMP BD project with one obtaining an MS degree in Biology and the other 10 still pursuing a PhD in their various fields. At the end of the BD program support, one BD fellow obtained a GRFP fellowship and 3 were awarded 2-year G-RISE fellowships. The rest were awarded teaching assistantships in their respective departments except for one student who was forced to take a medical leave of absence. All are currently graduate students in good standing in their respective departments. To date, these students have participated in the publication of 4 research articles and 6 abstracts and presentations at professional conferences. In addition, one recruit to the BD program who was unable to accept the offer at the time, returned to Rutgers University as a G-RISE Fellow the following year. In addition, an alumnus of the department of Earth & Environmental Sciences was so impressed with the BD project that they donated two years worth of funding for a stipend and tuition for an additional graduate student. This means that the BD project actually impacted 14 underrepresented minority graduate students. These two additional students are also intent on obtaining a PhD.


Last Modified: 06/10/2023
Modified by: Alexander E Gates
